makers.displaydate: 1881–1973; born Malaga, Spain; died Mougins, France; active Paris
makers.displaymaker: designed by Pablo Picasso, 1881–1973; born Malaga, Spain; died Mougins, France; active Paris

texts.textentryhtml: Norwegian artist Carl Nesjar executed Pablo Picasso's Head of a Woman in 1971 from a twelve-inch maquette that Picasso had completed in 1962. The huge project was poured and then sandblasted on-site. Picasso, who approved the project, received no fee for the work.

bibliography.boilertext: Patrick Joseph Kelleher, Living with Modern Sculpture: the John B. Putnam, Jr., Memorial Collection, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 1982).
bibliography.citation: Patrick Joseph Kelleher, Living with Modern Sculpture: the John B. Putnam, Jr., Memorial Collection, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 1982)., 92–95

bibliography.citation: Karin Dienst, ed., Sculpture of Princeton University: including works from the John B. Putnam Jr. Memorial Collection, (Princeton, NJ: Published by the Office of Communications, in association with the Princeton University Art Museum, 2004)., 44–45, illus.

bibliography.boilertext: Jane McCarthy and Laurily K. Epstein, A guide to the sculpture parks and gardens of America, (New York, NY: Michael Kesend Pub., 1996).
bibliography.citation: Jane McCarthy and Laurily K. Epstein, A guide to the sculpture parks and gardens of America, (New York, NY: Michael Kesend Pub., 1996).

caption: Executed by Carl Nesjar (Norwegian, 1920–2015), designed by Pablo Picasso (1881–1973; born Malaga, Spain; died Mougins, France; active Paris), Head of a Woman, Designed 1962, executed 1971. Cast concrete, granite, and quartzite; 488 × 365 × 218.4 cm. The John B. Putnam Jr. Memorial Collection, Princeton University (y1969-131)
